dataset.title: Diets and defenses: an examination of elephant foraging selection in Mapungubwe National Park, South Africa

individualName.surName: Nick Cuneo, Colin Donihue, Laurence Kruger (resource person), Cassandra Nuñez

abstract.para: Elephant populations in southern Africa have dramatically increased recently, impacting vegetation structure and reducing tree diversity. We observed and analyzed elephant foraging behavior to determine patterns in browsing preference for male and female elephants in three age classes in relation to forage characteristics. Elephants selectively browsed, generally preferring mechanically defended tree species to those with chemical defenses. Elephants targeted trees between 4 and 8 m tall significantly proportionally more frequently than any other size tree, lending more evidence that elephants are fundamentally changing vegetation structure. Females tended to have more selective diets due, we speculate, to their physiology than did males, and adults had a much greater impact on their environment than did juveniles or infants. Elephants have a significant effect on the vegetation structure in their environment, and the increasing populations are cause for concern. Patterns in environmental impact according to sex and age are necessary to inform decisions on elephant management, while patterns regard plant susceptibility are helpful in predicting changes in vegetation structure and composition.

section.para: This study was conducted in Mapungubwe National Park, part of
South Africa’s National Park system (SANParks). Mapungubwe is located in northern
South Africa and borders Botswana and Zimbabwe. Most of Mapungubwe is arid
mopane and acacia savanna with several riparian zones around seasonal waterways. The
study was conducted November 15th-17th. A table of all study sites along with their
respective start times, habitats, and GPS locations is included as Appendix A.
Study species. The African elephant, Loxodonta africana, is the largest mammal
in Africa with adults frequently standing three meters at the shoulder and weighing over a
ton. Females and juveniles typically form matriarchal pods containing 8 to 12 individuals
while males tend to be solitary and highly territorial, only visiting their pod for mating.
Twenty elephants were reintroduced in Mapungubwe in 2005 after being excluded for
approximately 50 years. A year later that population had risen to over 400 (L. Kruger
pers. comm.). Park management has never culled the elephant population, so their
demographics are not artificially skewed and the animals are relatively tolerant of
observation. The majority of the elephants migrate seasonally and sometimes daily
through holes in the fences to Botswana. It is clear from personal observation that the
border fences do not hinder the flow of elephants. While they are fairly well protected
from poachers in South Africa, their vulnerability to poaching across the border is
unknown. There are several impoverished settlements in the area which might hunt
elephants for food or to protect crops.
Plot design. We defined a vegetation-sampling plot as the circle of 25 m
diameter radiating around a feeding elephant. The plot incorporated all of the vegetation
choices that the focus elephant had within eyesight, so a comparison could be made
between vegetation available and vegetation browsed which would reflect the elephant’s
foraging preferences. We defined trees as single-stem vegetation as opposed to bushes,
which were multi-stemmed. We collected data from 25 plots.
Classification of elephants and browsing intensity. Infant elephants were those
lacking tusks and noticeably smallest in the herd. Juveniles were those elephants with
small tusks and body sizes less than 50 percent the size of the largest (adult) elephant in
the group. Adult elephants were those with developed tusks and massive bodies. All
solitary males were considered adults.
We observed two general types of browsing by elephants. The first was “mobile
browsing” while the elephant was walking purposefully forward. No data were taken to
quantify this. When an elephant stopped or significantly slowed its movement to browse
in a limited area—hereafter referred to as “stationary browsing”—a plot was declared and
data were collected on browsing impact. Low impact browsing events were defined as
leaf stripping. Medium impact browsing events were defined as branch breaking, and
high impact events were any that reduced the canopy of that tree by more than 25
percent.
Data collection. We located elephants, either by vehicle or on foot, and then
followed them on foot. We recorded GPS coordinates and time of arrival at every plot.
We also conducted a vegetation survey of the plot, recording the species and height of all
of trees present. The elephant or elephants were observed for the entire time they stayed
within the plot, and the age class, sex, targeted tree species, individual height, and
browsing event intensity were recorded. We followed elephants until they left the
confines of the park, became aware of our presence (and so altered their behavior), or
dusk fell.
Data analyses. Data analyses were performed using the StatView® statistical
package, with significance set at α = 0.05. To determine elephant preference and plant
susceptibility we used χ 2 contingency tables to compare data on what species and height
classes were browsed to what was available. When comparing preference among
elephant age and sex groups, we were careful to exclude species not present in similar
abundances during observations of all groups so as not to bias our results.
